metadata.case_name: State of Assam & Ors. v. Kripanath Sarma & Ors.

facts.text: In 1947, Assam Legislature passed Assam Primary Education Act, No. XIII of 1947, for development of primary education.

Assam Primary Education Act, 1947 repealed by Assam Basic Education Act, No. XXVI of 1954 (1954-Act), to provide for development, expansion, management and control of basic education and introduce universal, free and compulsory basic education.

1954-Act provided for State Advisory Board for Basic Education to advise State Government on matters relating to control of School Boards, grants, recruitment, conditions of service, training, curriculum, textbooks, medical inspection etc.

1954-Act constituted Regional Boards for Basic Education (School Boards) for each region in a district, with powers to control basic education, appoint and punish basic school teachers and attendance officers.
1954-Act repealed by Assam Elementary Education Act, No. XXX of 1962 (the Act), which came into force on October 5, 1962.
Section 3 of the Act constitutes State Board for Elementary Education (State Board), a corporate body with perpetual succession and common seal.

Section 10 of the Act defines functions of State Board, including laying down principles for grants to local authorities, procedure for recruitment of teachers, conditions for recognition/expansion/amalgamation/opening of schools, and other acts necessary for purposes of the Act.
Under Section 15, State Board performs duties per prescribed rules of business.
Main change in Act: School Boards under 1954-Act abolished; Deputy Inspectors of Schools became Assistant Secretaries of State Board with same headquarters/jurisdiction.

Section 14(3)(iii) authorizes Assistant Secretaries (Deputy Inspectors) to appoint teachers in recognised schools on advice of Committee under Section 16, transfer them, grant leave other than casual.
Section 16 authorizes State Board to constitute Advisory Committees for Section 14(3)(iii).
Section 34(2): On Act coming into force, all teachers/employees of School Boards taken over by State Board, with protection of emoluments and seniority.
Section 38: All existing teachers (or to be appointed) in recognised Elementary Schools deemed employed by State Board (except Autonomous Districts).
Section 54: State Government power to make rules.
Section 55(2): Savings clause - authorities constituted, appointments, rules etc. under 1954-Act deemed under the Act and continue until action under Act taken.
State Advisory Board continued post-Oct 5, 1962 until State Board constituted.
On November 20, 1962, State Advisory Board passed resolution: Subject to exceptions, all non-matriculate or non-T.T. teachers working in schools discharged w.e.f. 31-3-1963.

Secretary, State Advisory Board wrote letter dated (implied Dec 15, 1962) to Secretaries, School Boards (Deputy Inspectors as Assistant Secretaries): Enclose resolution, direct strict following for removal of non-T.T./under-matric teachers; submit statement of any retained post-31/3/1963 with reasons by 20/4/1963.

Post March 31, 1963, termination actions began; letter to Kripanath Sarma dated April 9, 1963: Service terminated with immediate effect under departmental instructions for removal of under-matric/non-T.T. teachers. H.P. Janigog No.1 L.P. School.
Similar termination letters to other respondent-teachers in May 1963, August 1963, September 1963; none before March 31, 1963.
Writ petitions filed in Assam High Court challenging termination orders; main ground: No authority under Act to terminate; alt: Violation of Art. 311(2).

High Court judgment dated September 9, 1964 in Civil Rules Nos. 115 etc. of 1963: Allowed petitions, set aside terminations; held s.14(3)(iii) no power for Assistant Secretary to terminate pre-Act teachers; State Board did not act under Act/rules.
Appeals to Supreme Court: 11 by special leave, 10 on High Court certificates.

legal_issues.text: Whether Assistant Secretary (Deputy Inspector of Schools) had power under s.14(3)(iii) of the Act read with s.18 of Assam General Clauses Act, 1915 to terminate services of respondent-teachers taken over under s.34(2).
Whether the State Board terminated the services of the respondent-teachers through the resolution of November 20, 1962 or the letter of December 15, 1962.
Whether termination orders were valid as actions by the State Board or delegation thereof.

petitioner_arguments.text: Under s.14(3)(iii) read with s.18 Assam General Clauses Act, 1915, Assistant Secretary had power to terminate as power to appoint includes power to dismiss/suspend.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.14(3)(iii) Assam Elementary Education Act 1962; s.18 Assam General Clauses Act 1915

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents were employees of State Board under the Act; services terminated by State Board in effect.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.34(2), s.38 Assam Elementary Education Act 1962

petitioner_arguments.text: Resolution of Nov 20, 1962 amounted to termination by State Board; or delegated authority to terminate.
Respondent-teachers not holding civil posts under State; Art.311(2) not applicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Secretary School Board/Assistant Secretary State Board had no authority under Act to terminate services.
Termination violated Art.311(2) as holding civil posts under State.
State Board did not terminate services; orders by Assistant Secretary without authority.

court_reasoning.text: Power to appoint under s.14(3)(iii) vests in Assistant Secretary though on advice of Committee; appointing authority is Assistant Secretary, so s.18 General Clauses Act confers power to dismiss those appointed by him.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appointment on advice/recommendation does not show different intention under s.18.

court_reasoning.text: Assistant Secretary cannot dismiss pre-Act teachers taken over under s.34(2)/s.38 as not appointed by him; no such office pre-Act; School Boards were appointing authorities pre-Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.18 applies only to persons appointed by the authority.

court_reasoning.text: s.55(2) deeming provision not applicable to teachers due to specific s.34(2)/s.38 deeming them employed by State Board.

Nov 20, 1962 resolution and Dec 15 letter lay down policy/principles for discharge from 31/3/1963, not termination orders; no list of teachers known; not communicated to teachers; letters post-31/3/1963 show no termination on that date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Resolution not order of discharge without communication to individuals (Bachittar Singh).

court_reasoning.text: No delegation by State Board; resolution silent on delegation; no indication to whom delegated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Delegation requires explicit resolution by State Board.

court_reasoning.text: Termination orders invalid as neither by State Board nor delegated authority nor by Assistant Secretary with power.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only two possibilities: State Board itself or delegated authority.

holdings.text: Assistant Secretary has no power under s.14(3)(iii) + s.18 General Clauses Act to terminate pre-Act teachers taken over by State Board.
Nov 20 resolution and Dec 15 letter are policy directives, not termination orders by State Board.
No delegation of termination power; termination orders invalid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bachittar Singh v. The State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Resolution not terminating services without communication to affected persons.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Elementary Education Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Constitution and powers of State Board, takeover of teachers, no power to terminate pre-Act teachers by Assistant Secretary.

statutes_cited.name: Assam Basic Education Act, 1954
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed; School Boards had appointment powers; savings under s.55(2) of 1962 Act.

statutes_cited.name: Assam General Clauses Act, 1915
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to appoint includes power to suspend/dismiss unless different intention.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Raised by respondents; not decided by High Court or SC.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs (one hearing fee), upholding High Court order setting aside termination orders of respondent-teachers as invalid, lacking authority under the Act.
outcome.relief_granted: Termination orders set aside (affirmed High Court).
outcome.costs: Dismissed with costs, one hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "Legally, a resolution like this cannot be read as an order dismissing persons whose names were not even known to the authority passing it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why resolution not termination order.

key_quotes.text: "the authority which appoints can only dismiss such persons as have been appointed by it."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits s.18 General Clauses Act to those appointed by the authority.

key_quotes.text: "In the face of these two specific provisions the general deeming provision contained in s.55(2) cannot be used."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Specific s.34(2)/38 prevail over general s.55(2).
